App description: From the co-creator of Rick and Morty comes Trover Saves the Universe. Your dogs have been dognapped by a beaked lunatic who stuffed them into his eye holes and is using their life essence to destroy the universe. You're partnered with Trover, a little purple eye-hole monster who isnt a huge fan of working or being put in the position of having to save the universe. Only you and Trover can save everything in this bizarre comedy adventure filled with combat, platforming, puzzles, and morally questionable choices  created by Justin Roiland! -Control Trover's movements, but not his mouth. Hes got a lot to say about whats going on in the game. -Travel the cosmos to experience a variety of weird alien planets and characters with big personalities. -Upgrade Trover AND YOURSELF with new abilities while evading awkward situations. -Immerse yourself in weirdness.

evandaganJun 25 at 5:42 PM
Moss 2

If you're looking for another diorama-style action-adventure puzzle platformer like Moss, this is it.

Seriously, the exploration, battle sequences and many of the environmental puzzles are very similar. Where this goes above and beyond Moss is in the ability to change camera position, and scenes/levels that are full 360-degree environments.

And that's just the gameplay - of course the voice acting and humor adds a whole other layer, and if you're a fan of Rick and Morty (or Accounting) you won't be disappointed.

My only complaints: I wish there was an option for free-spinning the chair by actually rotating your headset/body. I realize that this option would conflict with the "interact" function that is gaze based, but feel like some more effort could have gone to remapping controls for quest. But once you get used to it this is not a deal breaker.

Great game!

lORDOFTHEfLOODJul 10 at 7:03 AM
Brilliant game psychology

This game functions on an incredibly intuitive psychological level - the characters you grow to love (or hate) manipulate you in just the right ways to move forward with this joyously hilarious experience. First they destroy you with laughter, then they encourage you to delve into this amazing platforming design (which has in initially high learning curve, but is very rewarding once it becomes natural - make sure you learn the telekinesis chair upgrade well). Your new VR friends are encouraging to let go and actually enjoy something. If you miss this psychological element and just pound your way through like you do through more crudely designed games, you miss the entire point of the experience. Those that get it will thoroughly enjoy the end level of the main campaign . Seriously euphoric.

jelwellJun 23 at 1:11 AM
Mediocre Platformer, Stellar Humor

The Rick & Morty style humor is spot on. Occasionally the dialogue gets drawn out but theres always some mini activity you can do (like shooting trash balls into the basketball hoop) or you can often just cut the scene short if you really want.


The game itself is just ok. The Chairorpian mechanic seems clever at first but its really a way to lock you into essentially a 3DOF experience. The camera angles remind me of Super Mario 64 - limited control and not always where you want the camera to be.

The chair upgrades made for a good learning curve for controls. But the grab and move/rotate controls I struggle with every time. The on screen hints for which buttons to press for that make no sense. They should show the oculus controller and highlight the button to press. Instead Im presented with two gray shapes with L written on each shape and one of the shapes is moving. Thats not exactly clear. And even when you figure out which combination of buttons to press I find things rotating while moving and generally difficult to move things in some angles.

Was it worth the 27$ I paid. I guess so. But Im not sure Id buy a sequel.
